content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature, I would choose strategy R (R{}) for this game. The reason behind this is that while there is a possibility of losing rounds where both players choose differently, the potential gains are significantly higher when we both choose R (45$ per round) compared to B (35$ per round if the opponent chooses R and 40$ per round if they choose B). Moreover, in the long run, I believe that the high reward of 45$ per round outweighs the occasional losses. This strategy maximizes my expected payoff for the 75 rounds, assuming an unpredictable opponent.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

Given that I initially chose R (R{}), I will continue with this strategy for the next round as well. Since my opponent also chose R in our previous round, we both received a payoff of 45$. In this game, there are 74 rounds left to play.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

This will give me a higher payoff of 35$ compared to the 0$ I received in the previous round. I still believe that my risk-taking nature allows me to embrace new challenges, even if they involve uncertainty or potential loss.
